author: Nigel Slater
title: Nigel Slater’s winter citrus recipes | Life and style
text:
C itrus fruit makes the heart sing, it brightens, refreshes and uplifts: a thick, bittersweet orange curd; a salad of bitter leaves and pink grapefruit made piquant with tiny capers; a light, cooling ceviche of sea bass and blood orange, or cold-weather main dish of Italian boiling sausage, slow-cooked potatoes and lemons. There is no better time for those clean, vivid citrus flavours than now – frost on the hedges, the scent of lemon zest in the air.
Puntarelle, grapefruit and capers Some great things going on in this simple salad. Crisp, slightly bitter leaves, such as chicory or the long, jagged-toothed shoots of puntarelle, work well when dressed with something mild and buttery, like this dressing of citrus juice, capers and butter. The simplicity has something of a catch to it here, the dressing being easy to get wrong. I sometimes need more than one go at it. The butter needs to be lightly browned before you add the clementine juice. This needs a careful eye if it isn’t to burn. You need the toasty, nutty notes of the browned butter.
Serves 4
puntarelle or other bitter leaf 500g
grapefruit 1
small orange 1 small
clementines 2
butter 50g
capers 2 tsp, drained
Trim the puntarelle, removing any dark leaves, then put the pale tubular stalks into iced water. Leave for at least 2 hours.
Slice the ends from the grapefruit, sit it flat on a chopping board then slice away the peel and white pith with a knife. Be vigilant about removing the pith, as its bitterness can spoil the salad. Cut the grapefruit in half, then cut each half into thin slices. Do the same with the orange.
Drain the puntarelle and pat it dry with kitchen paper or spin briefly in a salad spinner. Toss the puntarelle with the grapefruit and orange. Halve the clementines and squeeze the juice, then set aside.
Make the dressing: melt the butter in a small, shallow pan, then, watching it carefully, leave it for three or four minutes until it starts to smell nutty. The butter should darken slightly in colour. As soon as the butter smells nutty, pour in the juice of the clementines, stir in the drained capers, then remove from the heat immediately.
Divide the salad between four plates, then spoon over the butter, caper and clementine dressing.
Ceviche of sea bass and blood orange 
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Ceviche of sea bass and blood orange. Photograph: Jonathan Lovekin for the Observer 
The texture of the marinated sea bass will mostly depend on the length of time it spends in the dressing. Two hours is just long enough for the sea bass to be tender and toothsome. Any longer and it may become too soft and woolly.
Serves 4
red onions 2
radishes 10
jalapeños 2
sea bass 4 fillets (about 550g total weight)
limes 3
blood oranges 2
sherry vinegar 2 tbsp
Peel the onions, then slice them into rounds no thicker than 1cm and put them in large glass bowl. Thinly slice the radishes and the jalapeños, then add them to the onions.

Slice the sea bass finely into strips about 1cm in thickness, then put them in with the radishes and onions.
Squeeze the limes and blood oranges – you need about 250ml – then season with the sherry vinegar, and a little salt and black pepper. Pour the juice over the fish and vegetables, cover and set aside, in the fridge, for about two hours. Serve on chilled plates.
Cotechino with potatoes and lemon 
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Cotechino with potatoes and lemon. Photograph: Jonathan Lovekin for the Observer 
The marriage of pork and lemon has long been a favourite of mine. This time, potatoes are roasted with lemon, olive and bay then tossed with pieces of juicy Italian sausage. Cotechino, the plump, sticky, boiling sausage, can be found in Italian grocers. It comes in a sachet, which you slip into cold water and bring to the boil. Beware the hot juices when you slip the hot sausage from its foil.
Serves 3
small, waxy potatoes 750g
lemon juice of 1
garlic 4 cloves
olive oil 4 tbsp
thyme 10 small sprigs
rosemary 4 sprigs
bay leaves 3
cotechino sausage 500g
Set the oven at 200C/gas mark 6. Wash the potatoes, then cut them in half lengthways and put them in a roasting tin. Squeeze in the lemon juice then add the empty lemon shells. Add the peeled garlic cloves, olive oil, thyme and rosemary, and a little salt and black pepper, then toss gently to coat the potatoes. Place in the preheated oven and roast for about 30 minutes till the potatoes are golden.

Put the cotechino, still in its sachet, into a deep pan of cold water and bring to the boil. Lower the heat to a simmer, cover with a lid and follow the timing instructions on the packet. (The cooking time will probably be about 20 minutes.)
Remove the cotechino from the water, open the pouch, carefully remove the sausage then cut into six thick slices. Tuck the slices among the potatoes and return to the oven for 10 minutes before serving.
Fig and orange shortbreads 
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Fig and orange shortbreads. Photograph: Jonathan Lovekin for the Observer 
Good as these fig cookies are, I like to dip them into the Seville orange curd (see recipe below) as I eat.

Makes approximately 12-16
For the fig paste
dried figs 150g
golden sultanas 100g
For the shortbread
butter 200g
golden icing sugar 90g
vanilla extract a few drops
ground almonds 140g
plain flour 190g
pistachio nuts 80g, shelled
orange zest of 1
To finish
icing suga r
rose petals 
Set the oven at 180C/gas mark 4. Place a piece of baking parchment on a baking sheet.
Remove and discard the hard stems from the figs, then put the figs into a food processor, add the golden sultanas and process to a coarse paste. Set aside.
Put the butter, cut into small pieces, into the bowl of a food mixer, add the icing sugar and beat, with a flat paddle beater, to a pale, soft cream. Pour in the vanilla extract, and blend in the ground almonds and flour. Roughly chop the pistachios and fold them in, together with the orange zest.
Lightly flour a chopping board. Take a tablespoon of the fig paste and roll it into a ball. Scoop up two tablespoons of the almond shortbread dough, roil it into a ball then press a deep hollow in the centre. Place the ball of fig paste in the hollow and draw the almond shortbread around it to completely enclose it. Flatten the balls lightly with a fork, then place on the lined baking sheet, with a little space between them.
Bake for 20-25 minutes until pale biscuit coloured, then remove from the oven and allow to cool. Sift icing sugar over the biscuits and, if you wish, scatter with dried rose petals.
Seville orange curd 
Facebook Twitter Pinterest Seville orange curd. Photograph: Jonathan Lovekin for the Observer 
Sharper than the usual lemon curd, with a delicious bittersweet marmalade tang.

Enough to fill a standard jam jar
lemons 2
Seville oranges 2
butter 100g
caster sugar 200g
eggs 3
egg yolk 1
Grate the zest from the lemons and oranges, using a fine-toothed grater over a heatproof glass or china bowl. Slice the fruits in half and squeeze the juice. You need a total of 240ml.
Place the bowl of juice and zest over a saucepan of simmering water. Cube the butter and add it, together with the sugar, whisking regularly. When the butter has melted, break the eggs into a small mixing bowl, add the egg yolk and beat lightly to mix. Stir the eggs into the fruit and butter mixture and continue whisking, often but not continuously, until you have a thick, custard-like consistency.
Remove the curd from the heat and leave to cool. Giving it the occasional stir. Transfer, with a rubber spatula, into a clean glass jar, cover and refrigerate.
